sp.l: Thou art a Boy, thy Father is a Fool,
Peneus a Dotard, all run up to Beard;
I have enſnar'd you all, to feed my Fiends,
As men hunt ſavage Beaſts to give their Dogs.
But Tyrants Furies are ſo highly fed,
That mine will ſcorn the Souls of ſuch damn'd Fools.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Y' embrac'd us all with Vows and Oaths and Smiles,
And promiſes of everlaſting love;
Can ſuch diſguiſes well become a King?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: They are thy Fathers own caſt Vizards all.
He embrac'd me with Vows and Oaths and Smiles,
Then made my Wife an everlaſting Whore.
Now more—the Caldron and the Fire.—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: To ſerve thee, as thy Father has ſerv'd me;
He has enkindled ſuch a Fire in me,
As boyls my Fleſh in my own ſcalding bloud.
I'le boyl thy Heart in thy own pureſt bloud,
To treat thy Father at thy Bridal Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh! Hell! all Hell is in your words and looks!
Why ſtart you not at your own dreadful voice;
For 'tis a Devils voice, and not a mans;
And Hell pours all its rage into your Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Then Hells an Aſs to throw away its rage,
On a heart, full as it cou'd hold before▪

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh! horrour!
Are theſe my Nuptial joys?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Such as thy Fathers fins provided thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh! my Antigone! Antigone!
Tyrant thank her for all the tears I ſhed.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Canſt thou be tortur'd with the loſs of her?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: More than with all thou canſt inflict beſides.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: By all thy torment then, gueſs half of mine,
Thou loſeſt but the half of what thou lov'ſt,
Only her ſight a while, and with no ſhame.
My Aerope was once as dear to me;
Her Heart was ſtollen, and body whor'd for me,
That I have loſt all of her, and with all ſhame.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I muſt acknowledge, Sir, your wrongs are great

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: And my revenge ſhall equal all my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But why on me? unleſs you mean to ſpare
My Father; and if ſo, pour all on me.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: I cannot wound they Father, but through thee

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh! ſpare me! ſpare me! for your own ſake
See the Gods threaten you in Prodigies.
Your Palace nods to bid you have a care.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: My Palace ſhakes for fear of its own Fate;
It did aſſiſt thy Father in his Crimes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The Temple Columns bend, to beg my life.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Did Gods come down to beg thy hated Life,
Into their Faces I wou'd ſpurt thy blood.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then you'l not mind their weeping Images;
Like frightned women in cold ſweats they reel.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Let frightned women mind 'em.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Th' Angry Gods
Dart fiery Javelins fiercely at your Head,
But miſs it, 'cauſe their hands with horrour ſhake.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Then I am here the only thing unmov'd,
And I dare do, what nothing dare behold.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes Tyrant, I dare ſee, and ſuffer too,
With greater courage, all thou canſt inflict,
Than thou darſt look on thy own frightful Soul.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: How now! what is this?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This is Philiſthenes,
Tyrant, thou never ſpok'ſt with me till now.
The wretched thing that tumbled at thy feet,
Was but a Garment which thou kep'ſt in pawn▪
Whilſt my Soul went to ſee Antigone▪
And take its leave; but now I am come home,
My Breaſt will meet thy Dagger when it dares.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: I thank you Gods I did not kill this Boy,
For of the ſudden he is grown a man.
Come Prieſts.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I, ever while you live call Prieſts,
If you wou'd have a ſolemn murder done.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Bind with a purple band the Victims head:
Perpare the Incenſe, Fire, Knife, wine and Meal.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Oh! ſpare your pains, Prieſts are not to be taught
The way to murder Princes decently,
As to your ſorrow you may quickly find
If any Rebels ſhall e're need your blood.
But I will give the remnant of my breath
In one full ſigh to dear Antigone!
What have I ſuffer'd long for a ſhort hope,
Which in a moment periſhes with me?
A ſhort ſweet hope was all I had of thee;
And a long mournful memory will be all
Thou, dear Antigone, wilt have of me.
But I will render it ſo glorious,
Thou ſhalt not be quite void of Nuptial joys,
As I am not in hopes thou all thy life
Wilt love my name, as I dye ſighing thine,
Antigone! oh! my Antigone▪

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Then dye!—'tis done—'tis well—'tis excellent.
So now Thyeſtes I ſhall bring thee in
A dreadfull ſcore for all thy pleaſant ſin;
Much doſt thou owe me, and much ſhalt thou pay;
Gods ask of him the blood is ſhed to day.
I lodg'd the Traytor, and he rob'd my throne,
And whor'd my Wife, for which I ſeize his Son,
If you have title to the blood that's loſt,
Purſue the Robber, not the plunder'd Hoſt.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Atreus and Thyeſtes. A Table and Banquet.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: COme Brother ſit;

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: May not Philiſtenes
Sit with us, Sir?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: He waits upon the Bride.
The Queen, the Bride, and Ladies are all ſat;
They are before-hand with us, let us haſte
To overtake 'em.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Let us bleſs the Feaſt
With the Brides health—Sir, to the fair Brides health.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: My moſt dear Brother, I will do you right.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: A deeper bowl; this to the Bridegrooms health.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This to the Gods for this moſt joyful day,
sp.stage: [Thy. pours ſome wine on the ground, both drink.
sp.l: Now to the Bridegrooms health.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: This day ſhall be
To Argos an Eternal Feſtival.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Fortune and I to day try both our ſtrengths,
I have quite tyr'd her left-hand miſery,
She now relieves it with her right-hand joy,
Which ſhe lays on me with her utmoſt force;
But both ſhall be too weak for my ſtrong Spirit.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: So! now my Engines of delight have ſcru'd
The Monſter to the top of Arrogance,
And now he's ready for his deadly fall.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Oh! theſe extreams of miſery and joy,
Meaſure the vaſt extent of a mans Soul,
My Spirit reaches Fortunes Eaſt and Weſt.
She has oſt ſet and riſen here, yet cannot get
Out of the vaſt Dominion of my mind.
Ha! my proud vaunting has a ſudden check;
See! from my Head my Crown of Roſes falls.
My Hair, though almoſt drown'd beneath ſweet Oyls,
With ſtrange and ſudden horrours ſtarts upright.
Something, I know not what, bids me not eat;
And what I have devour'd, within me groans,
I fain wou'd tear my breaſt to ſet it free.
And I have catch'd the eager thirſt of tears,
Which all weak Spirits have in miſery;
I who in baniſhment ne're wept, weep now.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Brother regard it not, 'tis fancy all.
Miſery like night is haunted with ill Spirits,
And Spirits leave not eaſily then haunts▪
'Tis ſaid, ſometimes they'l impudently ſtand
A flight of beams from the forlorn of day,
And ſcorn the Crowing of the Sprightly Cocks:
Brother 'tis morning with our pleaſure yet,
Nor has the ſprightly Wine Crow'd oft enough;
See in great Flaggons at full length it ſleeps,
And lets theſe melancholly thoughts break in
Upon our weaker pleaſures, rouze the Wine,
And bid him chaſe theſe fancies hence for ſhame,
Fill up that reverend unvanquſh'd bowl,
Who many a Gyant in his time has fallen,

And many a Monſter, Hercules.
〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: If he deſcends into my groaning breaſt,
Like Hercules, he will deſcend to Hell.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: And he will vanquiſh all the Monſters there.
Brother, your courage with this Hero try;
He o're our houſe has reign'd two hundred years,
And he's the only King ſhall rule you here.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What ails me? I cannot heave it to my Lips.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What▪ is the bowl too heavy?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: No, my heart.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: The Wine will lighten it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: The Wine will not
Come near my Lips.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Why ſhou'd they be ſo ſtrange?
They'r near a kinne.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: A kinne?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: As poſſible, Father and Son not nearer?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Does not good Wine beget good blood?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Your Lips then and the Wine may be a kin.
Off with your kindred Wine, leave not a drop
To dye alone, bewildred in that bowle.
Help him to heave it to his Head, that's well.

div.stage: Thyeſtes drinks; a clap of Thunder, the Table overſets, and falls in pieces; all the lights go out.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What ponderous Crimes pull Heaven on our Heads?
Nature is choak'd with ſome vaſt Villany,
And all her Face is black.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Some lights, ſome lights.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: The Sky is ſtun'd, and reels 'tween Night and Day;
Old Chaos is return'd.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: It is to ſee
A young one born, more dreadful than her ſelf,
That promiſes great comfort to her age,
And to reſtore her Empire.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Confuſion I have in thy bowels made.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Dire thoughts, like Furies, break into my mind
With flaming brands, and ſhew me what he means.
VVhere is Philiſthenes?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Ask thy own bowels:
Thou heardſt 'em groan, perhaps they now will ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Thou haſt not Tyrant—what?—I dare not ask—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: I kill'd thy Son, and thou haſt drunk his blood.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Oh! Villany ſo vaſt it broke the Poles;
And through the ſpacious flaw, Hell ruſh'd on Earth.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Thy groaning bowels call'd up Hell to Earth;
VVild beaſts will follow one anothers howles.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Hell came to have an interview with thee,
The greater Monſter; one whoſe Villany
Has ſcar'd away the Sun; he wou'd depoſe
Himſelf, e're lend thy wickedneſs his light.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: E're lend my Juſtice,—but he cou'd lend all
His wealth to help thee to corrupt my Wife;
That he and all the Gods may flye for ſhame;
They all combin'd to that; Gods ſtep'd the Mouth
Of blabbing Thunder, left it ſpoyl'd the ſport,
Nature cou'd ſee that ſight, and not be ſick,
Nor in diſorder rowl; as ſhe does now.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs, thy impious ſelf, or I
Wou'd make Hell ſtrain to out do us in ſin;
But of the three thou art the overmatch,
For Hell has bounds, thy wickedneſs has none.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: My juſt rewards of wickedneſs have none.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Oh! Gods! If I deſerve this puniſhment,
Revenge the Heavens plunder'd of their light:
Compoſe of lightning a falſe dreadful day,
And take no aim, but dart it at us both;
Hit one of us, and tis no matter which,
You ſtrike the wickedſt man that lives on Earth.
You will be merciful in burning me,
Make me become my dear Son's Funeral pile.
All Gods have left us but the Powers of Hell,
Thoſe only are fit to bear us Company;
And with a Sword I fear to end my grief,
Left I in my own boſom ſtab my Son.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: I never had thee in my power till now;
I had thy Fortune, Children, and thy Life;
But now theſe tears confeſs I have thy Soul,
And now I'm well rewarded for my pains.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: If now I ſhou'd not grieve, I were no man;
But a more horrid Monſter than thy ſelf.
What was my poor Sons fault?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: That he was thine.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And being mine, wou'dſt thou give me, give me
His blood to drink?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Who injur'd me but thee?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Bear witneſs Gods! he owns the innocence
Of this poor Youth, whoſe bloud he made me drink?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What Gods? the Guardians of Nuptial Beds?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Muſt ſin with ſin be puniſh'd?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: No, that ſin
Becomes a Vertue, that chaſtiſes ſin.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Oh! my poor Son!

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: All theſe are tears of rage,
'Cauſe I' a aforehand with thee in this ſin.
Thou with my Children wou'dſt have treated me,
But that thou wert afraid they were thy own
Inceſtuous Baſtards all.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I' ve done with thee,
And leave thee to the Gods for puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: But I've not done with thee; for though thy eyes
Pleaſe me with weeping, ſo they ſhall not ſcape.
The ſight of the remainders of thy Son,
And of her death thou lov'ſt above thy Son,
Shall tear 'em out, and then the work's compleat.
Open the Temple Gates, and call the Queen.
You mingled Luſts, now you ſhall mingle pains,
And through your Eyes, the paſſage of your Luſts.
Here ſhew the Father the Sons torn remains.

div.stage: [The Temple is open, Philiſthenes lyes bloudy.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Oh! my Philiſthenes! my mangled Son!
Had ever Hell ſuch cruelty as this?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Nor man ſuch Treaſon and ſuch luſt as thine,
Nor injur'd Monarch ſuch revenge as I.
Thy former Villany, and preſent Tears,
I'le caſt in Braſs, and in Effigie
I'le drag thee round all ages of the world.

div.stage: Enter Antigone in a raving poſture, women offer to hold her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stand off, I am not mad, but I ſhall be,
If this be true; it never can be true,
Oh! Sir, I've heard—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What have you heard?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh! Gods!
Oh! horrour!—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What's the matter with you?—ſpeak!
What have you heard?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have Kill'd Philiſthenes.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: There was no ſecret love between you? ha?

div.stage: Enter Aerope, between her two Children Agamemon and Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: What is the matter both with Heaven and Earth?
For every Face below is white as Death,
And Heavens Face above is black as Hell.
Sir, you was pleas'd to ſend for me they ſay?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: But I had come if you had not.
I was with my two little pretty Sons,
My Agamemnon, and my Menelaus.
When of the ſudden, with a thouſand groans,
The Air brought forth a monſtrous Shade, as black
As Hell had vomited a Lake of Pitch.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Thy ſins were then in labour, and brought forth
This bloody Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: Oh! moſt dreadful ſight!

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: The worſt I ever ſaw, except thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: My Child is murder'd!

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: By thy own luſt.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: No, by thy Perjury, inhumane Prince.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: How durſt thou name, or think of Perjury.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: That Villain clear'd the innocence the wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: I never will believe either him or thee.

sp.speaker: Aero.
sp.l: This bloody ſpectacle ſays that too loud.
I ſee a Dagger in my poor Childs hand.
I thank thee Daughter for this Legacy.
Now hear me Gods, for hear me well you may;
Born high on Innocence, I reach your Throne,
If e're in thought I yielded to that ſin,
For which I ſuffer ſo much miſery;
Kindle a Hell o' purpoſe for my Soul:
But if I undeſerv'd have born all this,
Then build a Heaven fit for my reward,
And I will lay the firſt Foundation Stone.
Thus, thus, thus;
Nay Villain I will lay you firm.
This for the loſs of my dear Husband's Love:
This for the loſs of my dear Daughters Life:
This for the ruin of my honeſt Name:
This for my Life I am about to loſe.
Now I have done my ſelf this little right,
I can with comfort dye!—oh! Sir, farewell;
You looſe a faithful Wife, what e're you think,
Made by great wrongs unfit for your embrace
But moſt deſerving your kind memory.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Oh! Sir! come here and ſee your workmanſhip.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Oh! my deluded miſerable age!
Have I toyl'd fourſcore years for Innocence,
And am I made a murderer at laſt?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Hence Hypocrite! thou never hadſt conceal'd
My lewd and Trait'rous Brother in thy Houſe,
So nurtur'd all his horrid ſins, when born,
But that thou wert a bawd to 'em before.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: An ex'lent thing it is to ſerve your houſe.
For Charity to him I'm call'd a bawd;
For ſerving you I'm made a Murderer.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: For ſerving my revenge I give thee Life;
But for concealing him, thy feeble Life
I cumber with the load of all this blood.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The ſcarlet Livery of your Family;
I wear your badge; Furies will know me now,
They are the Stewards of your Family,
They'l pay me all the wages I deſerve.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Go, for thy wages then—to Hell—begone—
Begone I ſay, and ſee my Face no more.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Wou'd I had never ſeen the face of you,
Or any of your impious Family.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Thruſt the old Traytour out, away with him.
I do no more by him, then Gods by me;
For I am driven by them from plague to plague.
Man is a vagabond both poor and proud,
He treads on beaſts who give him Cloaths and Food.
But the Gods catch him whereſoe're he lurks,
Whip him, and ſet him to all painful works.
And yet he brags he ſhall be crown'd when dead,
Were ever Princes in a Bridewell bred?
Nothing is ſinfully begot but he;
Can baſeborn Baſtards lawful Soveraigns be?
Confeſs it, was there? have you been ſo falſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh! Sir, you fill my heart with dreadful fears:
The news is true—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What's true?—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That you have kill'd—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: That you have lov'd my Enemy?—is that true?—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He is not, never was your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: But did you love him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes above my Soul.
VVe both lov'd long, above expreſſion lov'd,
Unknown to any but our faithful ſelves.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Haſt thou abus'd me ſo? why then let that
Which has thy Lover take thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What ſhou'd have damn'd Thyeſtes Son, but Hell?
If thou wilt take Hells leavings there thou mayſt.

div.stage: Atr. points to Phi. Ant. runs to him and falls at his feet in a Swoun.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh! my Philiſthenes! my murder'd Love?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: And, oh! my murder'd hopes! I thought this Maid
Had Vertues wou'd ſupport our falling Houſe;
I thought o'her ſide I was thunder proof,
And ſhe's as falſe as any of our Race,
A Traytreſs to her Father and her King.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now 'tis my turn, fell Tyrant▪ to inſult,
Thou haſt devour'd thy own beloved Child
As well as I, the Gods have given my heart
This Cordial of Revenge before I dye.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: She's none of mine.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: May they be curſt that wake thee from this Dream,
Till thou haſt ſhed thy Daughters innocent blood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh! horrour! horrour! my Philiſthenes
All mangled, torn, and gory!—horrour—oh!

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: How durſt thou, Traytreſs, love my Enemy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He had more worth than all our Race beſides,
None of our Race did e're deſerve to live,
But this ſweet Youth, and me for loving him.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: How dar'ſt thou talk thus? Fond Idolatrous Fool!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: After this murder, what have I to fear?
Nothing but Life, and keeping of my Wits.
Oh! with theſe words you have more cut my heart,
Than had you pierc'd it with a thouſand Swords;
For now I find 'twas I ſhed all this blood.
Oh! Gods! oh Father! oh Philiſthenes,
What have I ſpyed? The Knife that kill'd my Love?
Oh! you good Gods!
I thought a Prieſt ſhou'd once have joyn'd our hands;
But now this Knife ſhall mingle our hearts blood.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: What art thou doing there? thy looks are wild,
I like 'em not—to thy Apartment—go,
I can repair thy loſs, but the whole world
Can never repair mine, ſhou'd I loſe thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have ſo wounded my obedience,
By loving that dear Youth without your leave,
That 'tis too weak to hold my mighty grief,
Which forces me to dye without your leave.
Beſides, Sir, all the Gods have call'd me hence,
And ſent their pleaſure by this Inſtrument.
I come Philiſthenes—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Oh! hold her hand—
Too late, too late,
The Fatal blow is given;
Where had ſhe that accurſed Inſtrument?
She's paſt recovery! oh! my dear Child.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Oh! you juſt Gods!—

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Inceſtuous Traytor peace,
Thy Villany did help to murder her,
Thy guilt is greater, and I'm more enrag'd.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I ſcorn thy rage, for what have I to fear?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Look here, and think what thou haſt not to fear.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Ay, but look there, and what have I to fear?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: An age of lingring torments.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: That I bear
In this one minutes ſight of that poor Youth.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Then I will add.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: New will refreſh with change.
That Tyrant then does beſt, who uſes worſt,
A mutinous Impoſtour, ſo accurſt:
I'le breed with care theſe Boys for miſchiefs born,
That men may feel new Rods when th' old is worn.
WE ſhewed you in the Prieſts to day, a true
And perfect Picture of old Rome and new;
One Face ſerves both; Pagan and Popiſh Prieſts
Are but two names for the ſame bloody Beaſts.
Wonder not Poets ne're with Prieſts agree,
For Prieſts invade the Poet's Property.
Lying belongs to Poets; as appears
By old Preſcriptions of three thouſand years;
And Prieſts permit none but themſelves to lye,
Or thoſe that do't by Church-Authority:
Nay, they'l impoſe their lyes on you for true,
Which honeſt Poets ne're preſum'd to do.
They talk of being inſpired, but do moſt care,
To have you be ſuch Fools to think they are.
But when Prieſts meet in Councels, Synods, Claſſes,
They feign wou'd have you think Heaven Mounts the Aſſes.
The Devil rides 'em very oft 'tis true▪
When he has any curſed work to do;
But they have this damn'd fault in ways of ſin,
They run ſo faſt the Devil can't hold 'em in.
Then halter Prieſts, and tye 'em to the racks,
If you will keep the Devil off their backs:
But pray let Poets live, for they no ways
Offend you with damn'd Plots, but in their Plays,
And ask but half a Crown for holding forth,
And that's as much as any lye is worth.
